Award.AbstractNarration:
The spectral methods of automorhpic forms are basic tools of analytic number theory for more than three decades. Recently new possibilities have been opened in the area of metaplectic forms. The Proposal offers to make substantial expansion of the classical results to this territory, such as for example the large sieve for cusp forms. Applications of the spectral theory of metaplectic forms to the distribution of roots of quadratic congruences are in progress. Here the point is that the resulting estimates are valid in great uniformity with respect to the discriminant. Less direct, yet motivating are applications of spectral estimates in conjunction with sieve methods to the distribution of prime numbers. In particular these could yield a very good bound for the first prime which splits completely in the Hilbert class field.

The proposal also includes (jointly with B. Conrey and K. Soundararajan) study of zeros of L-functions, proving that a respectful percentage of such zeros lay on the critical line. This very basic problem (a progress towards the celebrated Riemann Hypothesis) will definitely attract graduate students. An interaction of the PI in the related research with students and postdoc is an indispensable part of the activity under the Proposal. In fact a current student Jorge Cantillo at Rutgers already began to work on improving the density theorems for the zeros of automorphic L-functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project concerns three different topics (spectral theory of automorphic forms, the theory of L-functions and the distribution of prime numbers) which are interconnected technologically. A considerable progress was accomplished by combining variuos methods from each of these areas. During the investigation some new features were revealed which improve our understanding of  involved questions. In particular, assuming certain relevant conditions, it was shown that there are infinitely many twin prime numbers by a method somewhat different than the original one due to R.Heath-Brown. Moreover, it was shown, again under similar conditions, that the Riemann zeta function has almost all its zeros on selected segments of the critical line. This result supports very nicely the celebrated Riemann hypothesis, which asserts that every complex zero rests on the critical line.

       There are two, diametrically opposite, methods for counting the critical zeros of the Riemann zeta function due to A. Selberg and N. Levinson, respectively. The latter has been substantially refined and improved by J.B. Conrey. One of the objectives of this Project was to make further improvements in collaboration with Conrey. It is clear that new proportion of the critical zeros can be now established by the ideas of this project, yet there is a chance for getting a considerably larger proportion which requires a lot more work.
